Material used.Description: Native N2A or N2A cell lines expressing WT or E163K DJ-1 were cultured separately into 48 well plates.

Readout description.Result Description: N2A cells expressing E163K mutant DJ-1 showed increased vulnerability to H2O2 exposure at all of the concentrations used. Cells expressing the E163K mutant lose the ability to protect against oxidative stress and even increases sensitivity to oxidative insult. Expression of E163K DJ-1 was able to protect against MG-132 and MPP dihydrochloride toxicity.

Technical replicates.Description: Each cell type was treated for 20 hours in sextuplicates with DMEM/FBS containing either 10, 20 or 30 uM H2O2, 7.5, 10, or 20 uM MPP dihydrochloride, 10, 20, or 30 uM MG-132.

Threshold for abnormal readout.Threshold for abnormal readout: Decreased cell viability at certain concentration of H2O2, MPP dihydrochloride, and MG-132.

Material used.Description: Native N2A, or N2A cells stably expressing WT or E163K DJ-1 were cultured in 10 cm plates.

Readout description.Result Description: Under conditions of oxidative stress, the E163K mutant demonstrated a paucity of localization towards mitochondria.

Basic positive control.Description: Native N2A, or N2A cells stably expressing WT

Threshold for normal readout.Threshold for normal readout: Under normal conditions, DJ-1 exhibited a diffuse staining pattern throughout the cell and co-immunofluorescence experiments with the mitochondrial marker, MitoTracker ® Red CMXRos, revealed some overlap with both WT and E163K DJ-1

Threshold for abnormal readout.Threshold for abnormal readout: Cells expressing the E163K mutant DJ-1 showed a paucity of localization towards mitochondria. It is possible that simply the change from a negatively to positively charged residue and/or the subtle structural effects discussed above may prevent the interaction of DJ-1 with other proteins that may be involved in the redistribution of DJ-1 under conditions of oxidative stress.

Material used.Description: N2A cells were cultured in 10 cm plates.

Readout description.Result Description: Endogenous DJ-1 protein was not pulled downed by immunoprecipitation with either WT-flag tagged or E163K-flag tagged DJ-1, indicating that there is no detectable formation of heterodimers between the endogenous DJ-1 and exogenous human DJ-1 protein.

Threshold for normal readout.Threshold for normal readout: There is formation of homodimers for wildtype.

Material used.Description: Native N2A, or N2A cells stably expressing WT or E163K DJ-1 were treated with DMEM/ FBS or DMEM/FBS containing 20 uM H2O2 for 3 hours.

Readout description.Result Description: Under the same oxidative conditions, cells expressing the E163K mutant DJ-1 showed a 6-fold decrease in the overlap with mitochondrial marker. E163K DJ-1 is impaired in its property to relocate in close proximity to the mitochondria, which may play a role in its inability to protect against oxidative stress.

Threshold for normal readout.Threshold for normal readout: DJ-1 exhibited a diffuse staining pattern throughout the cell and co-immunofluorescence experiments with the mitochondrial marker, MitoTracker ® Red CMXRos, revealed some overlap with both WT DJ-1

Threshold for abnormal readout.Threshold for abnormal readout: Cells expressing WT DJ-1 showed a 5-fold increase in staining overlap of the human DJ-1 protein with the mitochondrial marker as compared to untreated cells

Material used.Description: Native N2A and CHO cells or stable clonal lines expressing WT or E163K human DJ-1 were cultured in 10 cm dishes.

Readout description.Result Description: The WT and the E163K mutant form of human DJ-1 both were extracted most abundantly in the soluble Triton X-100 fractions (TX1 and TX2) and to a lesser extent in the RIPA fractions. Additionally, neither E163K mutant nor WT DJ-1 were detected in the SDS fractions, and there were no differences between the distribution of WT and E163K DJ-1 across any of the biochemical fractions

Threshold for normal readout.Threshold for normal readout: The WT and the E163K mutant form of human DJ-1 both were extracted most abundantly in the soluble Triton X-100 fractions (TX1 and TX2) and to a lesser extent in the RIPA fractions.

Material used.Description: N2A or CHO cells stably expressing WT or E163K DJ-1 were cultured in 6-well dishes.

Readout description.Result Description: Both the E163K mutant and WT DJ-1 proteins showed similar turnover in N2A cells, indicating that the E163K mutation does not result in reduced stability. Experiments were also performed in CHO cells and both protein variants also showed similar turnover rates in this alternate cell type.

Material used.Description: N2A or CHO cells and stable cell lines thereof were cultured in 10 cm dishes and grown to confluency.

Readout description.Result Description: Both the WT DJ-1 and the E163K mutant DJ-1 exclusively eluted in fractions 24 through 26, which corresponds to a molecular mass of ~42 kDa, the proposed molecular mass for the DJ-1 dimer. Endogenous DJ-1 protein expressed in N2A cells also eluted in the same fractions.

Threshold for normal readout.Threshold for normal readout: molecular mass of ~42 kDa, the proposed molecular mass for the DJ-1 dimer.
